page.title:
SOM Background
SOM Background
page.normal_text:
The Space Oblique Mercator (SOM) map projection was developed to support LandSat which covers the same large geographic extent as MISR.
The Space Oblique Mercator
(SOM) map projection was
developed to support LandSat
which covers the same
large geographic extent as
MISR.

SOM was designed to minimize the shape distortion and scale errors throughout the length of the MISR swath near the satellite ground track.
SOM was designed to minimize
the shape distortion and scale
errors throughout the length
of the MISR swath near the
satellite ground track.

SOM X is in the direction of the Spacecraft ground track and SOM Y is perpendicular X
SOM X is in the direction of the
Spacecraft ground track and
SOM Y is perpendicular X

page.title:
SOM Background
SOM Background
page.enlisting:
• Terra follows a pattern of orbits which repeats after 233 unique orbits • Each of the 233 possible orbits is called a path • SOM defines a separate projection for each of these paths • This path implies a specific longitude of ascending node, which implies • Terra follows a pattern of orbits which repeats after 233 unique orbits
• Terra follows a pattern of orbits which repeats after 233 unique orbits • T e r r a

page.title:
MISR HDF-EOS “Stacked Block” Background
MISR HDF-EOS “Stacked Block” Background
page.normal_text:
HDF-EOS routines do NOT assemble the blocks. That is left for the user.
HDF-EOS routines do NOT assemble the
blocks. That is left for the user.

180 blocks are defined for every MISR Product to make block index in absolute.
180 blocks are defined for every MISR
Product to make block index in absolute.

However, roughly 142 blocks have data for any given orbit. The extra blocks are to allow for seasonal variation.
However, roughly 142 blocks have data for
any given orbit. The extra blocks are to
allow for seasonal variation.

We are working on a Conventional Grid Product Specification that will not use stacked blocks, although we will preserve them for Standard Processing.
We are working on a Conventional Grid
Product Specification that will not use
stacked blocks, although we will preserve
them for Standard Processing.

page.title:
Where does this pixel belong with the MISR HDF-EOS “Stacked Block” Scheme?
Where does this pixel belong with the MISR HDF-EOS
“Stacked Block” Scheme?
page.enlisting:
• • Convert (block, line, sample) <-> SOM (x,y) – Requires several metadata values and some arithmetic. • Convert SOM (x,y) <-> Lat/Lon – Requires use of GCTP map projection coordinate conversion • Units: Integral block, fractional line/sample; meters x/y; decimal • This process is described in the MISR Data Product Specification, • Or simply look up the Lat/Lon of the corresponding block, line, •

Hdfscan For the “Stacked Block” Products
Hdfscan
For the “Stacked Block” Products
page.enlisting:
• Very useful during the debugging process • Displays all HDF-EOS Attributes, SDS’s, Vdata’s easily • Allows minor editing of the HDF-EOS file • Performs some statistics on the data • Does not assemble MISR blocks • Written in Fortran 90 and Tcl/tk • Only available on SGI Irix and Sun Solaris
• Very useful during the debugging process
• Displays all HDF-EOS Attributes, SDS’s, Vdata’s easily
• Allows minor editing of the HDF-EOS file

• Does not assemble MISR blocks

MISRView For the “Stacked Block” Products
MISRView
For the “Stacked Block” Products
page.enlisting:
• Maps path/orbit to time and date • Assembles MISR blocks • Reports Lat/Lon using the AGP • Displays true color MISR imagery • Can reproject MISR imagery • Requires IDL or IDL VM
• Maps path/orbit to time and date

ERDAS Imagine For the “Stacked Block” Products
ERDAS Imagine
For the “Stacked Block” Products
page.normal_text:
• Used to assist in validating the geo-calibration of MISR data. We wrote custom import routines to convert MISR HDF-EOS “Stacked Block” files into Imagine files preserving geo-location via stored metadata and projection parameters.

What is the “New” Conventional Grid Product?
What is the “New” Conventional Grid Product?

Tools To View Or Not To View the Conventional Grid Products
Tools To View Or Not To View T o o l s
T o
V i e w
O r
N o t
T o
V i e w
the Conventional Grid Products
page.enlisting:
• HDFView version 2.2 (free HDF browser, java based, NCSA) • Reads generic HDF files. • Displays stacked-blocks one block at a time. • Displays conventional grid products easily, as well as Level 3 products • No geolocation support. • ENVI verison 4.0 (commercial GIS, IDL-based) • Imports HDF, but not the HDF-EOS geolocation info. • Geolocation parameters can be set manually. • ENVI SOM projection agrees with MISR SOM. • Does not import HDF fields with more than 3 dimensions. • IDL version 6.0 (commercial Interactive Data Language) • HDF_READ() function. • Most flexible, yet involves coding in IDL. •MISRView (version 5.0) • Only supports stacked-block files. • HDFScan (version 3.5.3) • Displays metadata with no problems. • Does not display Conventional Grid data. Expects “SOMBlockDim” Dim. •ERDAS Imagine (version 8.7) • Does not support generic HDF or HDF-EOS import. • Does support geotiff (see HEG tool). • HDFView version 2.2 (free HDF browser, java based, NCSA)

page.title:
MISR Level 3 Data File Format
MISR Level 3 Data File Format
page.enlisting:
• Level 3 data files • In standard HDF-EOS grid format. • Not in more complicated stack block grid used by Level 1 and Level 2. • Can be read by any tool that knows HDF-EOS (i.e, IDL). • To simply view data, use Level 3 web page - no need to work with • Level 3 HDF-EOS data files can be downloaded directly from the • Level 3 data files

MISR Toolkit Application Programming Interface (API)
MISR Toolkit Application Programming Interface (API)
page.enlisting:
• The MISR Toolkit API will provide simplified • Will read MISR L1B2, L2 and conventional • There are no other tools available that • Abstract MISR “stacked block HDF-EOS grid” to a geolocated SOM projected plane with blocks assembled and fields unpacked and unscaled • Implemented using standard C, with wrappers for languages such as C++, Java, Python, Fortran, and IDL and will support variety of hardware architectures • The MISR Toolkit API will provide simplified

• Implemented using standard C, with wrappers for languages such as C++, Java, Python, Fortran, and IDL and will support variety of hardware architectures
